Keberatan Iuran BPJS Naik, Warga Bekasi Pilih Turun Kelas
01 Nov 2019, 04:30 by Antara, Clara Maria Tjandra Dewi H.
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Sejumlah peserta Badan Penyelenggara Jaminan Sosial (BPJS) Kesehatan di Kabupaten Bekasi memilih turun kelas bila iuran BPJS naik mulai awal tahun depan. Mereka merasa terbebani dengan kenaikan iuran itu.
M. Noval (33) warga Bekang, Desa Cibarusah Jaya, Kecamatan Cibarusah, mengatakan dia keberatan jika harus menanggung biaya iuran yang berlipat ganda. "Ya sangat membebani masyarakat karena masalah rencana kenaikan BPJS ini sudah sangat ramai di pemberitaan media hingga media sosial," katanya, Jumat 1 November 2019.
Sebagai peserta mandiri Kelas I, Noval mengatakan saat ini ia bersama istri dan satu buah hatinya membayar Rp240 ribu per bulan. Jika tetap memaksakan menjadi peserta Kelas I maka mulai tahun depan iuran yang harus dibayarnya untuk 3 orang menjadi Rp 480 ribu.
"Ya alternatifnya mau nggak mau harus turun kelas daripada harus membayar iuran sebesar itu tiap bulan," kata dia.
Clara Faradhika (24) asal Desa Sukasari, Kecamatan Serang Baru, juga merasa keberatan dengan kenaikan iuran itu. Meski mendapat subsidi sebagian dari perusahaan tempat suaminya bekerja, Clara menyatakan potongan gaji suaminya akan makin besar.
"Karena kalau naik, potongan gaji suami juga pasti akan lebih besar karena yang terdaftar ada empat anggota keluarga. Saya, suami, dan dua orang anak saya," katanya.
Pemerintah telah resmi menaikkan iuran BPJS Kesehatan mulai Januari 2020. Kenaikan iuran itu mencapai dua kali lipat dari tarif saat ini yakni kelas III mandiri dari semula Rp25.500 menjadi Rp42 ribu per peserta per bulan, kelas II mandiri naik dari Rp51 ribu menjadi Rp110 ribu, serta kelas I dari Rp80 ribu menjadi Rp160 ribu.
Keputusan iuran BPJS naik ini tertuang dalam Pasal 34 Peraturan Presiden Nomor 75 Tahun 2019 yang ditandatangani Presiden Jokowi pada 24 Oktober 2019 lalu.

Objection of BPJS Contribution Increases, Bekasi Residents Choose to Decline Class
01 Nov 2019, 04:30 by Antara, Clara Maria Tjandra Dewi H.
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - A number of participants from the Health Insurance Administration Agency (BPJS) in Bekasi District choose to drop out of class if BPJS contributions rise starting early next year. They feel burdened by the increase in fees.
M. Noval (33), a resident of Bekang, Cibarusah Jaya Village, Cibarusah District, said he objected if he had to bear the cost of multiplying fees. "Yes, it is very burdening to the community because the problem of the planned increase in BPJS has been very busy in the media to social media," he said, Friday, November 1, 2019.
As an independent Class I participant, Noval said that currently he and his wife and one baby pay Rp240 thousand per month. If he insists on being a Class I participant, starting next year the fee he has to pay for 3 people will be Rp. 480 thousand.
"Yes the alternative would not want to have to drop out of class instead of having to pay such a fee every month," he said.
Clara Faradhika (24) from Sukasari Village, Serang Baru District, also objected to the increase in fees. Despite receiving a partial subsidy from the company where her husband works, Clara said that her husband's salary deduction would be even greater.
"Because if it goes up, the husband's salary deduction will also be greater because four family members are registered. My husband, and my two children," he said.
The government has officially raised BPJS Health fees from January 2020. The increase in fees has doubled from the current tariff, namely class III Mandiri from Rp25,500 to Rp42,000 per participant per month, while Class II Mandiri has risen from Rp51,000 to Rp110,000, and class I from IDR 80 thousand to IDR 160 thousand.
The decision to increase BPJS contributions is contained in Article 34 of Presidential Regulation Number 75 of 2019, signed by President Jokowi on 24 October 2019.
